I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Key Indicators for Asia and the Pacific, prepared by the Economics and Research 
Department, is one of the annual flagship publications of the Asian Development Bank (ADB). 
The  publication  provides  the  latest  comprehensive  compendium  and  analysis  of  trends  in 
economic,  social,  financial,  and  Millennium  Development  Goal  (MDG)  indicators  of  ADB’s 
regional members. It also contains a special chapter that provides in-depth, data-intensive 
policy analysis of a prevailing critical policy issue. In general, Key Indicators provides a strong 
data and information support system for evidence-based policy making.  
2.  The Key Indicators series promotes ADB’s reputation as a knowledge institution and 
serves as an instrument for better informed policies and projects. To ensure that it does so 
effectively, it is essential that the topic of the special chapter is rigorously researched and that 
intensive  data  validation,  analysis,  and  compilation  are  conducted.1 This  process  involves 
extensive  collaboration  with  statistical  and  other  partners.  A  widespread  and  multipronged 
approach is used in disseminating the resulting publications. This technical assistance (TA) will 
ensure that these activities are carried out effectively. The design and monitoring framework is 
in Appendix 1.2 
3.  The Key Indicators special chapter is produced on a 2-year production cycle to allow for 
more  rigorous  and  systematic  analysis.  This  TA  will  support  the  preparation  of  the  Key 
Indicators 2015 (the 46th edition of Key Indicators). 
 
II.  ISSUES 
4.  Despite significant economic growth in Asia and the Pacific over the last 20 years,  the 
percentage employed formally has mostly remained stable or has modestly increased. This 
jobless  growth,  where  by  growth  fails  to  create  substantial  increases  in  better  jobs,  may 
potentially hinder Asia and the Pacific’s progress toward reducing poverty and becoming the 
leading region of consumption which drives global economic growth. In-depth research can 
provide an evidence base for ways to strengthen the linkage between expansion of better 
employment opportunities, which includes formal jobs and higher wages in the informal sector, 
and economic growth. It is necessary to have a macroeconomic overview and an understanding 
of the institutional and regulatory structures that directly or indirectly impede job creation, such 
as employment regulation, the business climate, openness to foreign direct investment, etc. 
However, this must be complemented by a microeconomic perspective, to provide evidence on 
the skill development of workers and managers, firm technology adoption, input allocations, and 
other firm-specific factors that can improve firm performance and competitiveness, such that it 
ultimately strengthens the linkage between growth and greater employment creation. While 
other studies have touched on similar issues, including the 2009 and 2011 issues of Key 
Indicators,  there  continues  to  be  a  need  to  better  understand  specific  microeconomic 
interventions and innovations that can be undertaken to improve macroeconomic development. 
Moreover, the intersection between labor market supply and demand through job matching 
continues to be relatively under-studied in the context of developing countries in Asia. 
5.  The Key Indicators is a premier knowledge product of ADB, consistently ranking as one 
of the top two most downloaded publications of all ADB publications in each year over the last 
five years.  In particular, the 2010 and 2011 KIs were downloaded 66,394 and 37,438 times 
                                                
1  The special chapter of Key Indicators for Asia and the Pacific 2013 was entitled “Asia’s Economic Transformation: 
Where to, How and How Fast?” It discussed the structural transformation taking place in Asia and the importance 
of having a balanced strategy of development in regard to industry and services. 
2  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 8 October 2013.

2   
(non-single page-nodes), respectively; while the 2012 KI was downloaded 30,969 times (single 
page-nodes) in the first year and a half of release.  To maintain its reputation as an important 
source of information, there is a need to improve the quality and relevancy of its contents.  Yet, 
the generation of knowledge has become increasingly more competitive, and maintaining the 
Key Indicators’ reputation as an important source of information requires continually improving 
the quality and relevancy of its contents.    In addition to the special chapter, the latest Key 
Indicators edition contained more than 120 statistical tables of indicators, grouped according to 
MDGs;  people;  economy  and  output;  money,  finance,  and  prices;  globalization;  transport, 
electricity, and communications; energy and environment; and government and governance.3 A 
short,  nontechnical  commentary  on  selected  indicators  precedes  each  of  the  groups.  To 
maintain relevancy and focus on current and emerging issues, each addition requires an early 
review  of  the  statistical  tables  to  identify  indicators  to  add  or  eliminate.  Similarly,  careful 
consideration needs to be given to the choice of indicators to be analyzed in the commentaries 
to ensure they reflect the impact of current developments across different themes.  To meet 
these objectives significant time and labor resources are required.  
6.  One of the key strategies outlined in ADB’s Strategy 2020 was inclusive growth.  The 
absence of a defined way to measure inclusive growth, however, made it difficult to identify how 
countries were performing and to understand how to enhance inclusive growth in the region.  
The Framework of Inclusive Growth Indicators (FIGI) was designed to make inclusive growth 
more  operational  by  identifying  indicators  that  depict  policy  aspects  of  inclusive  growth.  
However, significant effort is required to update and develop FIGI to gain broader support and to 
increase the usage of these measures to ensure they capture growth and well-being beyond 
simply gross domestic product. These measures are seen as a way to support ADB’s thrust to 
promote inclusive growth in the region, but require continued development and dissemination of 
the FIGI. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
7.  The  impact  of  Key  Indicators  2015  will  be  to  influence  the  environment  in  which 
economic monitoring and policy formulation, investment decisions, and new projects occur, 
especially in ADB’s developing member countries (DMCs). The outcome will be that by the end 
of  the  project,  Key  Indicators  2015  will  be  referred  to  by  policy  makers  and/or  economic 
researchers within and outside Asia, as well as by the general public. The improved content of 
Key Indicators 2015 will provide (i) information on trends and emerging issues that affect the 
development status of DMCs; (ii) high-quality data presented in the country, regional, and MDG 
tables; and (iii) indicators of inclusive growth for project planners, policy makers, researchers, 
and other users.  
8.  The outputs of the TA are as follows: (i) background papers and storyline for Key 
Indicators 2015 refined; (ii) final background research papers prepared for Key Indicators 2015; 
and (iii) publication and online links of Key Indicators 2015, statistical tables, FIGI, and special 
chapter.  
 
                                                
3  Key Indicators has five parts: Part I—Special Chapter; Part II—MDGs; Part III—Regional Tables; Part IV—
Framework of Inclusive Growth Indicators; and Part V—Definitions. Country tables containing socioeconomic data 
on developing member countries, Australia, Japan, and New Zealand, are available on CD-ROM or can be 
accessed online.

3 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
9.  For the Key Indicators to have a significant impact on the policy environment it is 
necessary (i) to develop relevant and unique content for the Key Indicators; (ii) maintain its 
credibility as source for statistics and development policy issues; and (iii) for the message and 
data  contents  of  Key  Indicators  to  be  effectively  disseminated  to  its  target  audience.    In 
preparing and enhancing the content Key Indicators 2015, workshops and seminars will be held, 
with invitees to include prominent researchers, key government officials, policy makers, and 
other key stakeholders. Workshops and seminars are crucial for (i) developing the special 
chapters,  (ii)  confirming  the  initial  findings  of  the  background  research  papers,  and  (iii) 
discussing  the  general  direction  and  unifying  theme  of  the  background  papers  to  ensure 
usefulness for the special chapters. Further, workshops and seminars may be held to look at the 
possibility of harmonizing inclusiveness with development effectiveness by analyzing economies 
in  Asia  and  the  Pacific  that  are  making  progress  in  reducing  poverty  and  inequalities. 
Distinguished experts will be invited to give their views so that the outputs of the workshops will 
be useful in finalizing the Key Indicators publication. Research, consultations, and discussions 
with staff from regional and other departments within ADB will also be conducted to further 
validate the relevance of the research findings, as well as to identify emerging concerns that 
could be potential topics for future Key Indicators editions. 
10.  For Key Indicators 2015, the special chapter will tentatively examine the issue of jobless 
growth by undertaking macroeconomic and microeconomic analyses. It will provide evidence on 
ways to improve the skill development of workers and managers to reduce skill mismatches, 
and pursue more efficient allocation of inputs, technology adoption, and innovations that can 
improve firm performance and competitiveness to strengthen the linkage between growth and 
employment creation. This study is related to a broader goal of providing an evidence-based 
perspective on ways to improve support for economic development and poverty reduction in 
Asia.  To enhance the quality, partnership with a top research center or institute in the area of 
labor, productivity and enterprise performance research will be developed.4 
11.  A series of internal meetings and workshops will be organized to further streamline the 
Key Indicators production process.  Production bottlenecks to be addressed will include staff 
and consultant assignments; overall coordination; development of commentaries; generation of 
country, regional, and MDG statistical tables; and consultant recruitment. System improvements 
will be carried out, including the interlinked processes involving the Statistical Database System. 
The use of C-cube as an additional platform for regular communications and data exchanges 
will be explored, including for sending out Key Indicators questionnaires and receiving replies, 
and for discussion forums including on best practice and methods.5 Close monitoring of the Key 
Indicators  process  will  mitigate  the  risk  of  unforeseen  circumstances  that  may  affect  the 
production schedule. 
12.  To improve the quality of Key Indicators, new regional aggregations may be introduced 
in the statistical tables. The aggregations are currently available but are limited to only a few 
indicators.  Compiling  aggregates  using  transparent,  consistent,  and  sound  methods  and 
practices will provide additional value to users. However, this may involve looking at different 
classifications  and  aggregation  practices  used  in  Key  Indicators  in  the  light  of  recent

Performance housed at the London School of Economics or the Institute of Labor Studies out of the University of 
Bonn. 
5  C-cube is a set of tools that link members through the web environment within and outside ADB, and allow them to 
communicate ideas and insights, coordinate tasks and events, and collaborate by sharing documents or holding

socioeconomic  developments  in  Asia  and  the  Pacific  and  practices  of  other  international 
organizations,  which  could  raise  complex  issues.  The  TA  will  support  the  development  of 
methodologies to produce the aggregations. 
13.  To ensure accuracy, coherence, and consistency of approach across the different parts 
of  Key  Indicators,  the  knowledge  products  will  undergo  stringent  editing  following  ADB’s 
Handbook of Style and Usage.6 Experienced international economics and/or manuscript editors 
will help prepare the publication’s chapters and highlights. Writer and copy editors will edit the 
regional  tables,  country  tables,  MDG  and  FIGI  tables,  definitions,  and  front  matter  of  the 
documents. 
14.  The Key Indicators 2015 will also contain a chapter on the Framework of Inclusive Growth 
Indicators (FIGI), which previously was produced as a special supplement in 2011–2013.7 The 
FIGI previously identified 35 indicators that depict policy aspects of inclusive growth. These 
include economic growth and employment opportunities, social inclusion, and social protection, 
as well as good governance and institutions.  A systematic review of the indicators will be 
undertaken to ensure FIGI maintains relevancy and to analyze a specific topic on inclusive 
growth that will further enhance ADB’s status as a promoter of inclusive growth in the region. 
15.  The Key Indicators publications will be widely disseminated in coordination with ADB’s 
Department of External Relations. Dissemination will start with an international media launch 
followed by seminar presentations to key government officials, business people, academe, and 
other research groups. Concurrently, the publications will be uploaded to the ADB website. 
Background papers will be published separately in ADB’s working paper series, the  Asian 
Development Review, or other media at a later date. 
16.  The TA will therefore support the following key activities of Key Indicators 2015: (i) 
updating, compiling, and validating data for the country, regional, and MDG tables; (ii) preparing 
background  papers,  including  data-intensive  research  related  to  the  theme  chapter(s);  (iii) 
drafting the theme chapter, FIGI, and thematic analysis; (iv) editing, layout, and printing of the 
Key Indicators main volume and the special chapter and Highlights of the Key Indicators for 
Asia and the Pacific; (v) disseminating the publications; and (vi) analyzing important policy 
issues related to emerging challenges for future special chapters of the Key Indicators series. 
Following the 2-year cycle, initial preparations for the Key Indicators 2016 special chapter may 
also be supported under this TA. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
17.  The TA is estimated to cost $750,000, which will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s 
Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-V). The cost estimates and financing plan are in 
Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
18.  ADB will be the executing agency. The Development Indicators and Policy Research 
Division (ERDI) of the Economics and Research Department  will implement the project in 
coordination with the regional departments, resident missions, and statistical partners in ADB’s 
member countries. The project will be implemented over 25 months, beginning on 1 December 
2013 with completion targeted for 31 December 2015.

19.  The Key Indicators is produced by a team consisting of ERDI international, national, and 
administrative staff with support from international and national consultants.8  For Key Indicators 
2015, an estimated 15 person-months of international consultancy services and 107 person-
months of national consultancy services will be needed for the entire production process, i.e., 
for the special chapter; the statistical tables (MDG, FIGI, country, and regional); and other 
developmental activities related to improving data quality and promoting effective dissemination 
of results and findings.  
20.  Consulting services are required to develop the different parts of Key Indicators. For the 
special chapter, international consultants will be collecting unique data, preparing background 
papers and original research material related to the theme, and providing manuscript and 
economics editing. National consultants will provide specific insight and research into country 
case studies and assist in data cleaning, calculations, and some analytical research.9  
21.  For the statistical tables (MDG, FIGI, regional, and country) and commentaries, an 
international or national consultant may be engaged to develop the aggregation procedures and 
other methodologies or innovations that will contribute to increasing the interest for users of the 
publication. An international consultant will also be recruited to draft the commentaries. Both 
staff and national consultants will assist in preparing the statistical tables, charts, boxes, and 
commentaries; laying out the text and tables; and copy editing. National consultants will assist in 
updating, validating, and further researching the indicators; laying out text and tables; and 
manuscript or copy editing.10  
22.  Resource people will also be engaged for 2–3 days each to contribute as facilitators, 
speakers, or panelists for Key Indicators workshops for the special chapters, supplements, and 
statistical tables. Travel may also be supported for ADB staff participating as resource people in 
related  workshops,  conferences,  or  seminars,  following  the  appropriate  administrative 
guidelines. 
23.  All  consultants  will  be  recruited  individually  and  selected  on  the  basis  of  their 
qualifications  for  the  assignment.11 The  outline  terms  of  reference  for  consultants  are  in 
Appendix 3. The international and national consultants, as well as resource people, will be 
engaged  by  ADB  in  accordance  with  its  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of  Consultants  (2013,  as 
amended from time to time). Disbursements under the TA will be made in accordance with 
ADB's Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). 
Appendix 4 presents the tentative outline of Key Indicators 2015. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
24.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $750,000 on a grant basis for 
the Key Indicators for Asia and the Pacific 2015, and hereby reports this action to the Board. 
                                                
8   ERDI has also discussed possible collaborations with RSGS staff on work related to the special chapter. 
9  National consultants will be hired in various countries throughout the Asia and the Pacific region for work related to 
the special chapter. They will be identified after further assessment of the viability of conducting research in those 
countries and highlighting of specific interesting cases related to the special chapter. For the statistical work, most 
of the consultants will be Philippine nationals as they need to be based in ADB headquarters for close monitoring 
of their work. 
10  ERDI’s standard process uses TA funds to facilitate the hiring of a manuscript editor, graphic designer, and writer 
and copy editor for the Key Indicators due to the need and urgency to have these people available in the final 
stages of the development of the publication. 
11  Individual consultants are being proposed, as opposed to a firm, due to the need to hire people that have very 
specific expertise in either a specific topic or country of interest. Experience has shown that few firms can provide 
the same level of expertise sought for developing knowledge products. ADB staff will serve as team leaders for 
teams of individual consultants.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Economists (international, three consultants, 10 person-months total, intermittent)  
 
1.  The  consultants  should  have  a  strong  background  in  development  economics, 
economics, or other related subjects. The consultants should also have expertise or interests in 
Asian economies. He or she will carry out the following activities: 
 
(i)  document policies and interventions that enable countries to promote inclusive 
and  sustainable  growth  in  Asia  from  the  perspective  of  education  and 
employment generation, private sector development, and firm productivity, and 
through regulatory constraints (one topic will be chosen for each consultant); 
(ii)  use data from selected developing member countries (DMCs) to document or 
highlight unique findings that will provide perspective on the issues, and how 
issues  on  jobless  growth  could  be  addressed  through  education,  firm 
development, or regulation; 
(iii)  undertake rigorous analytical research using valid econometric approaches and 
modeling techniques to provide detailed insights on an area related to the special 
chapter topic; and 
(iv)  provide advice on the direction of research for the special chapter and potentially 
contribute subsections to the special chapter, with the following specific tasks:  
 
(a)  review draft outline of special chapter or subchapter prepared by Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) staff and provide comments and suggestions 
for its finalization; 
(b)  brainstorm on potential terms of reference for background papers that will 
be funded through ADB related to the topic;  
(c)  attend  workshops  and  provide  comments  and  suggestions  for  the 
finalization of background papers; 
(d)  provide advice to authors of the background papers as required; and 
(e)  draft a paper that will serve as one of the key highlights in the special 
chapter, to be presented in one or two workshops. 
 
2.  The output for each of the three consultants will be a background paper for the special 
chapter. 
 
B.  Economists, Statisticians, Data Specialists (national, 12 consultants, 36 person-
months total, intermittent)  
 
3.  The national consultants should have a well-rounded knowledge of labor market policies 
in their countries. They should also be knowledgeable about sources of good data and have the 
ability to access this data, or be capable of collecting the data through surveying techniques. 
They  should  also  have  the  ability  to  analyze  the  data  using  statistical  and  econometric 
techniques. The tasks assigned are as follows: 
 
(i)  describe major policies and interventions on supply and demand for labor in their 
country, or perform analytical work on specific datasets; 
(ii)  synthesize findings in a report; 
(iii)  potentially help design and field survey; 
(iv)  provide inputs to Development Indicators and Policy Research Division (ERDI) 
staff and international consultants regarding policies and interventions prevalent

in their country, which can be used to evaluate the impact of selected policies 
and interventions; and 
(v)  present a paper or analytical work in one or two workshops. 
 
4.  The output of the national consultants will include background papers or country-specific 
case studies for the special chapter. 
 
C.  Manuscript and Economics Editor (international, 2 person-months, intermittent)  
 
5.  The manuscript and economics editor will be responsible for the manuscript-editing of 
the Key Indicators special chapter and assist in preparing the Highlights of the Key Indicators for 
Asia and the Pacific 2015, including the tables and charts appearing in the publication. He or 
she will also assist with the preparation of the highlights and presentation materials for the Key 
Indicators launch. 
 
6.  The consultant will review and edit the special theme chapter, statistical commentaries, 
and sources for the graphs and tables of the Key Indicators 2015 in line with the ADB Handbook 
of Style and Usage. The work includes a number of editing rounds of the typeset version until 
the  desired  quality  is  achieved.  The  manuscript  and  economics  editor  will  also  make 
suggestions regarding layout of the publication. In particular, the editor will carry out the following 
tasks for the special chapter and highlights: 
 
(i)  reorganize  the text  so that the  subject matter  is  easy to  understand  and  is 
logically presented;
